content:
That 'account' is Local Folders, and cannot be removed. If it's been renamed to a mail account such as user@host.com, that is incorrect and misleading.

But it's possible in 115 to hide LF (see picture).
creator: sfhowes

content:
Spacing: I found that there are additional font size settings in the corner menu completekly separate from the font size settings in the preferences, and these ones can fix font sizes and line spacing. But not switch fonts or margins, I still need to use my own css for that.

Colors: I swiched back and forth between the system theme and other themes and eventually Thunderbird started using the colors in my system theme.

This makes the question moot for me.

content:
V mnohých prípadoch pomôže opraviť priečinok, - kliknite na priečinok "Doručená pošta v Místní složky" pravým tlačidlom myši a zvoľte "Vlastnosti" a vyberte "Opraviť priečinok": http://imgbank.cz/images/2014/09/23/Thunderbird_opravit_priecinok.jpg - postupne opravte aj ostatné priečinky

Potom je nutné "Vykonať údržbu priečinkov": - Thunderbird - Súbor - Vykonať údržbu priečinkov http://imgbank.cz/images/2015/08/19/Thunderbird_udrzba_priecinkov.jpg
creator: Ansamb

content:
- click settings>general and scrollodown to config editor - search for toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets and change to true - then you need a folder named 'chrome' in profile, and a userChrome.css file in the folder (with content shown below). - exit and restart TB and it should work, although I've sometimes found I have to restart TB twice to see changes in userChrome.css - Below is content for userChrome.css 

/*  #######    */ @namespace html url("http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml");  #toolbar-menubar {   order: 1;              }  unified-toolbar {   order: 2;              }  #tabs-toolbar {   order: 3;               }
creator: davidsk

content:
Hi oldbob2,

I had this problem too (among many others) and I did find a fix.

In the unified folder list on the left side-bar, if you RMB-click on the Trash section header, you'll see a properties option at the bottom.

Select this and then click the Choose button as illustrated in the images below to select which accounts/trash folders should be included in the Trash section. Check each account's "Trash" folder is checked, if it's a Gmail account you might have to expand the Gmail folder to see it.

Once done, click OK and then Update...

Worked for me, hope it does for you.

-b
creator: psychprod1

content:
(I know, I know; following up my own post.) After messing about with this for a while, I discovered that the options become un-greyed-out, and the sorting starts working again, when those columns ("Order Received") are selected for display. So I think there are at least two bugs here:

  1. On upgrade, a working configuration silently stops working because the user-specified sort order becomes non-functional making new messages invisible.
  2. Sorting has a new and non-obvious dependence on display selections causing a regression in available functionality -- I have to change the displayed columns in order to change the sort order.
creator: carlsonj

content: The problem may be exactly as described: a network error. You may have a poor connection that cannot be resolved by an email client. I have experienced this on occasion and the solution was to save to local folder.
creator: davidsk

content: If both PCs used save version of TB, the layout should be the same. If one was 102 and the new is 115, then expect some differences, as 115 is intentionally different. Simplest approach: - exit TB on both PCs - copy profile from old PC: c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird - paste to same location on new PC. You will be prompted for overwrites. Allow - restart TB on new pc
creator: davidsk

content: I am not a Linux expert, but to clarify: if the zip just email folders, or is it the full profile? Assuming a full profile, my suggestion is to first unzip and then use tools>import>import from another thunderbird installation. If it is just email folders, I suggest unzipping and copying the individual folders to Mail\Local Folders.
creator: davidsk

content:
Try this to change the row height in the Threads Pane: 

@namespace html url("http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml");  /* threads pane line height */ html|tr[is="thread-row"] {    height: 24px !important;}


Help/Troubleshooting Info (TB 115), Profile Folder, Show in Finder, close TB, create a new folder named chrome, create a new document in chrome with a text editor, name it userChrome.css, Save as type: All files *.*, copy in the above code, change the number as desired. Double-click toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets to true in Settings/General/Config. editor, restart TB.

Online css generator

To set the font size, include this line: 

font-size: 18px !important;
creator: sfhowes

creator: davidsk

content: If I am misunderstanding, please accept my apologies. When you set up an Outlook account, it will be available at outlook.com because that is the home of the account. Thunderbird is an email client that helps you manage the account more effectively. So, that means you can access your account in both places if desired. That also applies to Gmail. Thunderbird is an email client and can never be the sole owner of an email account. There must always be an email host that makes the account available, and then Thunderbird helps you manage it. Most users rely solely on Thunderbird, using the website interface with email host only when account problems surface. I hope this is helpful. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: Assuming this is a POP account, you have a bit of work ahead. My suggestion is to copy the message folders from old profile and based into Mail\Local Folders folder. Then, copy the recent mails into that folder so they're all together. Then, exit TB, and copy the updated local folder to overwrite the message folder in the account. To be safe, do backups first.
creator: davidsk
